Only one (1) on-site Garage Sale sign shall be permitted on the front lawn of the property and not in the parkway or in public right-of-way, in addition to the Garage Sale Permit Sign. One (1) additional yard sign will be permitted in the side yard of those residences that are located on a corner lot. All other items which are intended to draw attention to the Garage Sale, including but not limited to banners, balloons, streamers, and the like are strictly prohibited. 
F.  Directional Signs . Two (2) directional signs for any one (1) Garage Sale shall be allowed, subject to the following restrictions: 
1.  Each sign shall not exceed six (6) square feet in gross surface area per sign face. 
2.  Each sign shall denote the address of the Garage Sale. 
3.  Signs shall be elevated to height no greater than three (3) feet from the ground to the top of the sign. 
4.  A sign shall not be placed in any manner to obstruct any line of vision for drivers of any vehicle. 
5.  Garage Sale Directional signs to the same address may be posted only with the permission of the property owner. 
6.  At no time shall signs advertising Garage Sales be erected on any public right-of-way, street sign, utility pole, or traffic control device. 
G.  Sign Placement and Removal . All signs authorized under the provisions of this section shall not be placed before 6:00 a.m. on the first day of the Garage Sale and signs authorized under the provisions of the chapter are to be removed no later than two (2) hours after the conclusion of the sale, or by 8:00 p.m. at the latest. 
(Ord. No. 4252-2011, § 2, 6-27-11; Ord. No. 4272-2011, § 2, 9-19-11; Ord. No. 4416-2014, § 1, 2-17-14) 
ARTICLE 8. - MERCHANTS (SERVICE) 

Sec. 8-8-1. - Automatic dry cleaning machines. 
A.  Definition. "Automatic Dry Cleaning Machine" shall mean any device or apparatus for the cleaning of clothes or fabrics, and designed to be used or operated by any but the owner, or any employee of the owner thereof, which machine or device makes use of or contained Perchloroethylene or any other chemical solvent or substance which may cause harm to human beings by reason of inhalation or contact. 
B.  License Required. It shall be unlawful to install any automatic dry cleaning machine without first having secured a license therefor. Applications for such license shall contain full information as to the mechanical equipment of such machine and provisions for ventilation for both the machine and the room in which the machine will be located. It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of maintaining any such machine for use by the public upon payment of a fee, without having first secured a license therefor. 
C.  Regulations. The applicant shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement and Fire Department. 
D.  Hours. No self-service dry cleaning establishment shall be operated between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:30 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-2. - Carters. 
A.  Definitions. 
1.  Cart shall mean every truck, wagon, automobile, autocar, auto truck or other vehicle of any kind, which shall be operated, driven or employed for the purpose of transporting or conveying bundles, parcels, furniture, trunks, baggage goods, wares, merchandise, produce or other articles within the Village for hire or reward, shall be deemed a cart for the purposes of this Chapter, whether such vehicle is employed or hired from any public stand, public way, garage, office or other place in the Village, by the day, month or year. 
2.  Carter shall mean any person engaged in the business of operating a cart. 
B.  License Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a carter without having obtained a license to do so. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-3. - Cleaners and dyers. 
A.  Definition. "Cleaning and Dying Establishment" shall mean any place or vehicle service where the service of dry cleaning, wet cleaning as a process incidental to dry cleaning, dyeing, spotting, and/or finishing any fabric is rendered for hire, or is sold, resold or offered for sale or resale. 
B.  License Required. No person shall engage in the business of operating a cleaning and dyeing establishment without having obtained a license to do so. 
C.  Regulations. The applicant shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement or Fire Department including inspection before issuance of license. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-4. - Contractors. 
A.  License Required. No person, firm or corporation shall conduct, manage, operate or carry on the business of: 
1.  General Contractor 
2.  Concrete or Cement Contractor 
3.  Mason (brick or stone) Contractor 
4.  Carpenter Contractor 
5.  Pavement Contractor 
6.  Siding Contractor 
7.  Excavating Contractor 
8.  Mechanical Contractor 
9.  Roofing Contractor 
10.  Swimming Pool Contractor 
11.  Fire Suppression Contractor 
12.  Sewer Contractor 
13.  Tree Service Contractor 
All other contractors engaging in the construction, erection, finishing, repair, wrecking or alteration of buildings or other structures within the Village of Hoffman Estates must obtain a license, when a permit is required, as hereinafter provided. 
B.  Exceptions to Electrical, Plumbing and Roofing Contractors. The licensing or certifying of any Master Plumber or Journeyman Plumber by the State of Illinois shall be deemed to be sufficient. An Electrical Contractor shall be licensed by an accredited licensing commission. The Master Plumbing license, Journeyman Plumber license or Electrical license will be deemed as qualifications to carry on a business in the Village without further license or application for license to this Village. 
C.  Application. Any person, firm or corporation desiring a license to carry on the business of Contractor as described in the first section of this Article, and engaged in the construction, erection, finishing, repair, wrecking or alteration of any building or dwelling shall make application to the Department of Code Enforcement stating in such application the name and residence of the applicant, if an individual, and the officials, if a corporation, and the place of business and the kind of contracting business proposed to be carried on by said applicant, and the experience which said applicant has. 
D.  Investigation. The Department of Code Enforcement shall cause an investigation to be made of the statements in such application and as to whether the applicant has the necessary experience, qualifications and equipment to properly engage in the proposed business. 
E.  Approval. The Department of Code Enforcement may approve the application and cause license to be issued. 
F.  Regulations. The applicant shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-5. - Department stores. 
A.  License Required. No person, firm or corporation shall operate or conduct a department store without obtaining licenses required. The licenses required, and the fees therefor, shall be as may be required by this Chapter for any item, article or merchandise, sold within the department store or business or type of business carried on within the department store, as if such item, article or merchandise or business or type of business were sold or carried on to the exclusion of all other business. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-6. - For profit schools. 
A.  Definition. "For Profit School" may mean any building, room enclosure, premises, place or establishment in the Village where instruction is given, and where a charge or fee for such instruction is made, paid or received. 
B.  License Required. No person shall conduct or operate any For Profit School in the Village without having obtained a license therefor, except where said For Profit School is under the exclusive license of the State of Illinois. 
C.  Regulations. The applicant shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-7. - Hotels. 
A.  Definition. The term "hotel" when used in this Code shall mean every building, structure or any part thereof used, kept or maintained as or advertised or held out to the public to be an inn, hotel, family hotel, apartment hotel, lodging house, motel, dormitory or other place where sleeping accommodations are furnished or maintained for hire or rent for 20 or more transient persons, whether with or without meals. 
B.  License Required. No person shall conduct, keep, manager or operate, or cause to be conducted, kept manager or operated, a hotel without obtaining a license therefor. 
C.  Register. The proprietor, manager, keeper or clerk of every hotel shall keep a register in which shall be entered the name, and if a transient, the permanent address and license plate number, if any, of every person who becomes a roomer, boarder, lodger or paying guest therein. Such register shall also show the number of the room occupied by such person, the date of his arrival and the period for which the guest engaged board or lodging. The register shall be accessible, without charge, to the Police Chief or any police officer. 
D.  Regulations. Each applicant shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement, Police Department, Fire Department. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-8. - Housemovers, houseraisers and shorers. 
A.  Definition. "Housemover," "Houseraiser" or "Shorer" shall mean any person engaged in the business of moving, raising or shoring houses or buildings in the city. 
B.  License Required. No person shall engage in the business of a housemover, houseraiser, or shorer without having obtained a license therefor. 
C.  Bond. Before said license shall be issued, such applicant shall execute a bond to the Village in the sum of $5,000.00, conditioned for the faithful observance and performance of all the provisions of this Code relating to or concerning the shoring, raising or moving of houses or buildings within the city, and conditioned, further, to pay all damages which may occur to any public way, or to any pole, wire, cable or electrical appliance or to trees or shrubbery owned or under the control or jurisdiction of the Village or to the property of any person in the Village caused by, or arising out of any act or thing done by such licensed housemover, houseraiser, or shorer, in and about the moving or raising of any house or building in the Village or in shoring, or which shall be done by any licensed housemover, houseraiser, or shorer under and by virtue of the authority given in this Article. 
D.  Permit Required. No licensee under this section shall remove any building from one place to another within the city without a permit issued for that purpose by the Department of Code Enforcement. 
E.  Regulations. The applicant shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-9. - Insurance-Foreign fire insurance companies. 
A.  License Required. It shall be unlawful for any corporation or association not incorporated under the laws of the State of Illinois to engage in effecting fire insurance in the Village or to transact any business of fire insurance in the Village without fully complying with the provisions of this Article. 
B.  Reports. Every person acting as representative for or on behalf of any such company or association shall, on or before the fifteenth day of July of each year, render to the Village Treasurer a full, true and just account verified by his oath of all premiums which shall have been received by him on behalf of the company during the preceding year ending the first of July on such fire insurance policies. 
C.  Time of Payment. All payments under the provisions of this Article shall be made on or before the fifteenth day of July following the termination of the year for which such payments are due. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-10. - Itinerant merchants. 
A.  Definition. "Itinerant Merchant" or "Transient Vendor of Merchandise" under this Article is hereby defined as one who is carrying on a merchandise business in the Village and holds more than a six month lease and less than a year's lease on a store, warehouse, office space or showroom. 
B.  License Required. It shall be unlawful to do business in the Village as an itinerant merchant without having secured a license therefor. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-11. - Laboratories. 
A.  Definition. "Laboratory" shall mean any building, place of establishment maintained or operated for the purpose of making medical, bacteriological, pathological, physiological, serological, chemical, industrial, agricultural, physical, dental, optional, veterinary, pharmaceutical, engineering, electrical, X-ray, or other scientific examinations, analysis, determinations or experiments. 
B.  License Required. No person shall conduct or operate any laboratory or laboratory agency for a fee without having obtained a license therefor. 
C.  Regulations. The applicant shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement including inspection before issuance of license. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-12. - Laundries. 
A.  Definition. "Laundry" shall mean any place, building, structure, room, establishment or portion thereof, which is used for the purpose of washing, drying, starching, or ironing shirts, dresses, underwear, collars, cuffs, or other wearing apparel, table, bed or other household linens, towels, curtains, draperies or other washable fabrics, such work being done for the general public. 
    It shall also be held to include any towel or linen supply laundry maintained or operated for the purpose of washing, drying, starching or ironing towels, aprons, napkins, table linens, washable clothing, or other similar articles, the property of such laundry, but rented or loaned for a consideration to patrons or customers of said laundry. 
    It shall also be held to include any establishment wherein washing machine units are available for use by the general public upon the deposit of a coin or the payment of a fee to the operator of such establishment or his agent. 
B.  License Required. No person shall engage in the business of any laundry within the city without obtaining a license so to do. 
C.  Regulations. The applicant shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-13. - Laundry vehicles. 
A.  Definition. "Laundry Vehicle" shall, in this Chapter, be construed to mean any wagon, automobile, or other vehicle used for the purpose of collecting or delivering laundry within the Village limits. 
B.  License Required. No person shall operate, or cause to be operated, on any of the public ways of the Village, any laundry vehicle without having obtained a license for the same. 
C.  Name of Laundry on Vehicle. No vehicle of any kind shall be used for the purpose of collecting or delivery of laundry work, unless said vehicle shall carry upon two sides of the same, in plain legible letters, at least one and one-half inches high, the name of the laundry where the laundry work is actually done. 
D.  Regulations. The applicant shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-14. - Motor vehicle repair shops. 
A.  Definition. "Motor Vehicle Repair Shop" shall mean any building, structure, premises, enclosure or other place where the business of doing repair work on or for motor vehicles or any of the component parts thereof, the replacing of or the adding of parts thereto or the polishing, washing, greasing, painting or refinishing of such vehicles, is carried on. 
B.  License Required. No person shall engage in the business of a motor vehicle repair shop without having obtained a license therefor. 
C.  Location. No motor vehicle repair shop shall be conducted or operated within 200 feet of any building used as a hospital, church or public or parochial school, or the grounds thereof. 
D.  Frontage Consents. No person shall construct, conduct or operate any motor vehicle repair shop in the Village on any lot in any block in which 2/3 of the buildings on both sides of the street are used exclusively for residence purposes, or within 100 feet of any such street in any such block, without the written consent of a majority of the property owners according to frontage on both sides of the street; provided, that all lots which abut only on a public alley or court shall be considered as fronting on the street to which such alley or court leads. 
E.  Vehicles. It shall be unlawful to store or park damaged vehicles or junked vehicles in any open lot or premises open to the public view. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-15. - Pet shops and kennels. 
A.  Definitions. 
1.  Kennel shall mean any person, partnership or corporation engaged in the business of breeding, buying, selling or boarding animals of any species. 
2.  Pet Shop shall mean a commercial establishment where dogs, cats, birds, fish, reptiles or others customarily obtained as pets are bathed, clipped, plucked or otherwise groomed or displayed for sale, exchange or adoption. 
B.  License Required. It shall be unlawful to keep or maintain any Kennel or Pet Shop within the Village without obtaining a business license therefor. 
C.  Regulations. The licensee shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement and the State of Illinois. 
D.  Operation. Every Pet Shop shall operate its business in full compliance with this Article, as well as all State and Federal laws relating to animal health, sanitation, disease prevention, as now or hereafter amended. All licensed premises shall be kept free and clear of decaying food and filth of any kind and shall be maintained in a sanitary condition at all times. 
E.  Disclosures Required. Every Pet Shop is required to post the information set forth below on a disclosure statement for each dog and cat for sale in a location where the disclosure statements are easily accessible, without request, by the public. If it is not detrimental to the dog or cat, the disclosure statement shall be placed on the animal's cage. If it is not in the best interests of the animal to place the disclosure statement on an animal's cage, there shall be a notice on the cage telling the customer where in the Pet Shop the disclosure statements can be found. 
    The disclosure statement provided by the Pet Shop to the customer shall include contact information for the Village's Department of Code Enforcement to be signed by the customer with that record to be maintained by the Pet Shop for not less than two (2) years. 
    The disclosure statement shall include, at a minimum, all of the following information: 
1.  The breed, approximate age, sex and color of the animal. 
2.  The date and description of any inoculation or medical treatment the animal has received prior to or while in the care of the Pet Shop. 
3.  The breeder's business name(s), mailing address, breeding location address if different from the mailing address, as well as any other alias name used by the breeder. 
4.  If the breeder is licensed by the United States Department of Agriculture, the current license number, as well as any other license numbers held within the last five years. 
5.  The USDA website. 
6.  Whether the breeder is a "hobby breeder", meaning the breeder has less than five female dogs or cats, as applicable. 
7.  The lineage (sire and dam) of the dog or cat, if known. 
8.  The address of the location where the dog or cat was born, as well as the location(s) where the dog or cat was housed after birth if different from the breeder's address as listed in subsection 4., above. 
9.  Any transfers of ownership of the dog or cat prior to its sale by a Village Pet Shop and, if the dog or cat was returned to the Pet Shop by a customer, the date the dog or cat was returned and the reason for the return. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11; Ord. No. 4552-2016, § 2, 7-18-16) 
Sec. 8-8-16. - Photographers. 
A.  Definition. "Photographer" shall mean any person operating, managing, or maintaining a photographic studio, a postcard studio, tin-type or ferrotype studio, a bromide enlarging plant, an amateur finishing or developing plant, or a portrait-copying house, or engaging in the business of photography, including commercial, portrait, and home portrait photography, or the business of a lantern slide marker, or of an itinerant or transient photographer, or the business of photography for any purpose whatsoever. 
B.  License Required. No person shall engage in the business of a photographer without having obtained a license therefor; provided, however, that the provisions of this Chapter shall not apply to photographing for or developing of motion picture film. 
C.  Regulations. The applicant shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement and Fire Department. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-17. - Public passenger vehicles. 
A.  Definitions. Unless otherwise stated, the following terms shall, for the purpose of this Article, have the meanings indicated in this section: 
1.  Inspection Station shall mean facility as approved and designated by the Chief of Police to conduct inspections as required by this Article. 
2.  Livery Vehicle shall mean any public passenger vehicle having a rated seating capacity of not more than seven persons, transporting passengers for hire, as a result of an individual contract, on a trip or hourly basis. 
3.  Owner shall mean every person, firm or corporation having the use or control of one or more public passenger vehicles. 
4.  Public Passenger Vehicle shall mean taxicabs and livery vehicles used for transporting persons for hire. 
5.  Public Passenger Vehicle Chauffeur shall mean any person who drives a public passenger vehicle for the transportation of persons for compensation. 
6.  Public Passenger Vehicle Company shall mean any person engaged in business as a proprietor of one or more public passenger vehicles for transportation of persons for hire. 
7.  Public Passenger Vehicle Owner shall mean any person owning or leasing from another, a public passenger vehicle for hire. 
8.  Taxicab shall mean all motor propelled vehicles, having a rated seating capacity of not more than seven persons, carrying passengers for hire indiscriminately, accepting and discharging all such persons as may offer themselves for transportation. 
9.  Taxicab Stand shall mean any place, public or private, where taxicabs are placed on display and presented for hire to prospective customers. Examples are: railroad stations, hotels, motels, bowling alleys, theaters and other prominent gathering places. 
10.  Taximeter shall mean any mechanical, electro-mechanical or electronic device which records or indicates a charge or fare measured by distance traveled, waiting time and extra passengers. 
11.  Waiting Time shall mean time when the taxicab is not in motion, beginning with the arrival at the place to which it has been called, or the time consumed while standing at the direction of the passenger. No charge shall be made for time lost due to inefficiency of the taxicab or its operator or time consumed by a premature response to a call. 
12.  Village shall mean the Village of Hoffman Estates, Cook and Kane Counties, Illinois. 
B.  Business License Required. 
1.  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to engage in the business of operating public passenger vehicles within the Village, without first obtaining a business license. 
2.  The license application will contain the same information as is required by the Village for all businesses, and shall be accompanied by an application providing all of the following additional information, as applicable, if not on the standard application form. 
a.  In the case of an individual-The name, date of birth and address of the applicant. In the case of a partnership-The persons entitled to share in the profits. In the case of a corporation for profit or club-The state and date of incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, names and addresses of the officers and directors, and shareholders and the percentage of ownership of each. Corporations whose stock is traded publicly and listed on recognized stock exchanges shall be required to identify only a holder of a majority of the outstanding shares of the corporation. 
b.  The citizenship of the applicant, place of birth, and if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of naturalization. 
c.  Current occupation/employment, business address and telephone number. 
d.  Educational background. 
e.  Previous employment history in the past five years. 
f.  Previous military history (if any) and type of discharge. 
g.  Current financial status, including any unpaid judgments and pertinent information relating to any such judgments. 
h.  Any previous traffic, misdemeanor or felony convictions. 
i.  Previous residences for the past five years. 
j.  The number of vehicles to be operated or controlled by the applicant and the location of the proposed depots and terminals. 
k.  The color scheme or insignia to be used to designate the vehicle(s) of the applicant. The color scheme or insignia shall be readily distinguishable from that of emergency vehicles and vehicles of previously licensed public passenger vehicle companies. 
l.  Any further information as may be required by the Village. 
3.  No public passenger vehicle may be licensed or may operate in the Village without proof of insurance in the amounts as required by this Code. 
This minimum coverage shall be: Not less than $250,000.00 per personal injury to one person and not less than $250,000.00 per incident. 
4.  No public passenger vehicle business license may be sold, assigned, mortgaged, pledged or otherwise transferred. 
5.  Every public passenger vehicle business owner shall keep in service at all times while his license is in effect, regular telephone service within the Village, by means of which a person desiring to hire a public passenger vehicle may call the business. The business owner shall cause the telephone number to be listed in the local and regional telephone directories which are published for the municipality by the telephone company which furnishes local telephone service in the municipality. 
6.  Every public passenger business owner shall operate every public passenger vehicle regularly in the Village to the extent reasonably necessary to meet the public demands for passenger service. They shall maintain a telephone or internet system for the purpose of receiving calls and dispatching vehicles. They shall answer all calls received by them for service within the Village as soon as possible and if said service cannot be rendered within a reasonable time, they shall notify the passenger(s) how long it will be before the service can be rendered and give the reason for the delay. Anyone who shall refuse to accept a call anywhere within the Village at any time where there are vehicles available, or who shall refuse to give overall service, shall be deemed in violation of this Article. 
C.  Public Passenger Vehicle License Required. 
1.  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any public passenger vehicle or engage in the business of operating public passenger vehicles within the Village, and including the operation of one or more such vehicles, without obtaining a public passenger vehicle license for each such vehicle operated, as provided in this section and otherwise conforming to the requirements of this Code. 
2.  Applications for public passenger vehicle license shall be made by the business owner upon forms furnished by the Village. A separate application and license is required for each vehicle to be operated in the Village. Such applications shall contain the full name and address of the business owner, and in the case of a partnership or corporation, the names and addresses of the officers or partners. Also required is a complete description of the vehicle, including make, model, seating capacity (excluding driver's seat), state license plate number, color of vehicle, engine horsepower and any other data as the Village may require. 
3.  The Village Clerk shall issue a public passenger vehicle license after the vehicle has passed the inspection as required by this Article. 
4.  The numbered vehicle license decal shall be affixed to the certified inspection plate, which shall be visibly displayed on the left side of the rear bumper. 
5.  It shall be unlawful to transfer any public passenger vehicle license from one vehicle to another. 
6.  The Village Clerk shall keep a register of the vehicle licenses granted, the date issued, the number of the license and the description of the vehicle licensed. 
D.  Inspection. 
1.  All public passenger vehicles licensed in the Village are required to be inspected three times per year at an approved inspection station. 
2.  Such inspection will include but not be limited to the following: vehicle make, model year and vehicle identification number, state license plate number and expiration date, odometer reading, mirrors, body damage, bumpers, headlights, taillights, registration lights, brake lights, hazard/warning lights, turn signals, doors and latches, trunk and hood, spare tire, identification markings, horn, defroster, wipers/washer, windows, front/rear floors, seats/seat belts, gauges, rates displayed, brakes-Front/rear/emergency, ball joints, wheel bearings, tires, steering, shocks/springs, linkages/seals, exhaust, current bond sticker, current emissions sticker. 
3.  Any vehicle failing to pass the inspection will be allowed five working days for repairs. The vehicle cannot be used as a public passenger vehicle for hire until repairs are completed and the vehicle passes a reinspection. If the vehicle does not pass reinspection within five working days, the vehicle license may be suspended. 
4.  The Chief of Police shall designate those facilities which are approved to conduct inspections as required by this Article. Those stations may be within or outside of the Village. He shall establish procedures for conducting the inspections and shall supply those inspection stations with inspection forms, numbered certified vehicle inspection stickers and other supplies as may be needed. 
5.  A list of the approved inspection stations shall be available at the Village Hall and shall be given to each public passenger vehicle owner with the notice of required inspection. An owner may use the approved inspection station of his choice, however, if a vehicle fails an inspection, once repairs are made, the vehicle must be reinspected at the same inspection station. 
6.  The inspection stations shall charge a fee as approved by the Village Manager for each public passenger vehicle inspected. 
E.  Vehicle Identification. 
1.  Every taxicab licensed in the Village shall bear on both sides of the vehicle, in a color contrasting to the color of the vehicle, the name of the company and its phone number. The lettering shall be a minimum of two inches in height and 1/4 brush stroke. 
2.  The identification number assigned to the taxicab by the company shall appear on both exterior sides of the vehicle at a minimum of three inches in height and 1/4 brush stroke and also in a conspicuous place in the passenger area at a minimum of four inches in height. 
3.  No taxicab shall be painted or labeled so as to be so similar to the vehicles of any others licensed for business in the Village so as to be an imitation and/or calculated to deceive the patrons of taxicabs into believing that such vehicles are in reality the taxicabs of the other. 
F.  Chauffeur License. 
1.  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any public passenger vehicle for hire in the Village without first having obtained a valid public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license from the Village. 
2.  It shall be unlawful for any person owning or controlling any public passenger vehicle to employ or permit any person to operate such vehicle for hire within the Village unless such driver has a valid public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license issued by the Village. 
3.  The application for a license for a public passenger vehicle chauffeur shall contain the name of the applicant, his residence and employment history, status of his current Illinois driver's license and the license number, whether his driver's license has ever been suspended, canceled or revoked and if so, why and when, and a list of convictions, if any, for violation of federal, state or municipal laws. 
4.  Applicants are subject to the following qualifications: 
a.  Shall be no less than 18 years of age. 
b.  Must pass a physical examination by a licensed physician, at his own expense, subject to the examination conditions on the form provided by the Village. Such certificate sets forth the opinion of the examining physician that the applicant is physically able to drive without risk to the public. 
c.  Must hold a valid Illinois driver's license. 
d.  Must not have been convicted of a felony or Class A misdemeanor within the past five years. 
e.  Must not have had his driver's license suspended or revoked in any state within the past three years as a result of violations of law concerning the operation of motor vehicles. 
5.  The Chief of Police shall cause an investigation to be conducted of each applicant, to include fingerprinting, and a traffic and arrest record. 
6.  The chauffeur's license shall be displayed at all times in the public passenger vehicle in plain view of the passenger. 
7.  It shall be unlawful to transfer any public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license from one person to another. 
8.  A public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license may be suspended for a period not to exceed 30 days for any failure or refusal to comply with the provisions of this Article, or upon a determination that said license was obtained fraudulently, or upon determination that the license owner has become physically, mentally, or emotionally unfit to perform his duties as a public passenger vehicle chauffeur, or that there has been fraudulent use of the public passenger vehicle chauffeur's license by or with consent of the license owner. 
G.  Public Passenger Vehicle Operation. 
1.  No operator of a public passenger vehicle shall carry more than a rated passenger load per vehicle. 
2.  After a public passenger vehicle has been hired by one or more persons traveling together, the operator shall not pick up other persons without the expressed permission of the person(s) first hiring the public passenger vehicle. An appropriate sign shall be posted indicated the restrictions on share rides. 
3.  No driver of a public passenger vehicle shall seek business by repeatedly or persistently driving his vehicle to and from in a short space before any theater, hotel, motel, railway station, or other public place or otherwise interfere with the proper and orderly access to or egress from any such place. 
4.  The operator of any taxicab may, in advance, demand payment of the fare from the person(s) desiring to be carried by such taxicab. The operator may also refuse to convey any person(s) who shall not comply with the demand; however, no operator shall refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person, upon request, unless previously engaged or unable to do so. 
5.  Advertising on public passenger vehicles shall be restricted to that which may be displayed on a light mounted on the top of the vehicle. 
6.  Subject to the conditions and limitations of this Article, permission and authority are hereby granted to the business owners hereunder to operate the taxicabs licensed in the Village upon the public streets and other public ways within the Village unless terminated or revoked. It shall be unlawful for any public passenger vehicle not licensed by the Village to solicit business in the Village or to accept for transportation any passengers within the Village. 
7.  Nothing in this Article shall be construed to prohibit any public passenger vehicle from coming into the Village to discharge passengers accepted for transportation outside of the Village. No person shall solicit for business from any place in the Village unless that person and vehicle is licensed in the Village. 
H.  Taxicab Rates. Reasonable rates of compensation may be set by an owner or operator of a taxicab and such rates shall be filed with the Village Clerk at least 30 days prior to implementation. 
I.  Posting Established Rates. There shall be affixed inside each taxicab in a place conspicuous to any person riding in such taxicab, in a frame covered by glass or other transparent material, a rate card issued by the Village, upon which card shall be printed in plain, legible type, the rates of fare. 
J.  Taximeters. 
1.  No taxicab shall operate with passengers for hire unless the taximeter is accurately recording the fare to be charged. 
2.  The taximeter shall be located so that its face can be seen by a passenger from the rear compartment of the vehicle. 
3.  Adequate lighting facilities shall be provided for illuminating the face of the taximeter so that it may be read by the passenger whenever the vehicle is in operation. 
K.  Fixing of Rates Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation licensed under the provision of this Article to conspire among themselves or with other persons to fix or control rates for taxicab hire within the Village. It is the purpose of this Article to provide for free and uncontrolled rates. Any scheme, device or other subterfuge employed by any business owner to evade this purpose shall be deemed to be in violation of this Article. 
L.  Operation of Livery Vehicles. 
1.  Livery vehicles shall not pick up or solicit passengers for hire from the streets. 
2.  Livery vehicles shall not park in taxicab stands. 
3.  Livery vehicles shall be limited in their scope of operation to varying passengers for hire on a contract basis at a price agreed upon prior to employment and by arrangement of the parties at the time of initial telephone contract by the customer to the livery company. 
M.  Senior Citizen/Handicapped Reduced Fare Taxicab Rate Program. 
1.  Rates to be charged persons who are 60 years of age or older, disabled persons, and low-income persons by taxicabs licensed to operate in the Village to such persons for transportation shall be based on the fare shown on the taxicab meter minus $5.00 for trips that begin or end in the Village. Trips to and from airports are not eligible for the taxi subsidy. 
2.  Persons eligible for the rates set forth in subsection M-1 of this Section must apply for and obtain an identification card issued by the Village. The Village shall establish the standards and procedures for the issuance of such cards. 
3.  No taxicab company shall, prior to pick up of said passenger, require that a prospective passenger identify if such person is a senior citizen, disabled person, or low-income person as defined by the Village. 
4.  No taxicab company, owner or operator of a taxicab shall refuse to convey any orderly person holding a valid identification card issued by the Village. 
5.  Those taxicab owners or drivers of taxicabs licensed by the Village shall bill the Village on a regular basis not less than monthly for the Village's share of such subsidized taxicab rate program, provided the following procedures have been met: 
a)  That the senior citizen/disabled/low-income person has presented their identification card issued by the Village at the inception of the taxicab ride. 
b)  The senior citizen/disabled/low-income person shall present one "coupon" issued by the Village to the driver with information including the resident's identification number, date of use, trip origin and destination, and total fare charged (not including tip). 
c)  That said "coupons" shall be forwarded to the Village for payment. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-18. - Refuse collectors. 
A.  Definitions. 
1.  "Refuse Collector" shall mean any person, firm or corporation engaged in the removal of refuse, debris, commercial waste, industrial waste and the disposal of table refuse or food matter usually known as garbage, from private dwellings, stores, offices, industries, hotels and motels, restaurants, cafes, clinics, hospitals, health care facilities, and other places not otherwise provided for by the Village. 
B.  License Required. No person shall engage in the business of refuse collection without obtaining a license therefor. 
C.  Provision of Recycling Services Required. 
1.  As a condition of receiving, maintaining and renewing a Refuse Collector's license within the Village, each licensee or applicant for such license shall establish and maintain the capability of providing recycling collection services to multi-family properties in the Village as required by Section 7-9-1-J of the Hoffman Estates Municipal Code. 
2.  As a condition of receiving, maintaining and renewing a Refuse Collector's license within the Village, each licensee or applicant for such license shall establish and maintain the capability of providing recycling collection services to commercial, institutional and industrial properties in the Village as required by Section 7-9-1-K of the Hoffman Estates Municipal Code. 
3.  A license certification form shall be submitted to the Village in conjunction with an application for the issuance or renewal of a Refuse Collector license. The format of such form shall be as prescribed by the Village of the purpose of providing information reasonably necessary to determine the applicant's capabilities to perform the required recycling collection services. The Department of Code Enforcement shall review the information, and may make one or more inspections of the applicant's processing facilities, to determine such capabilities. Approval of the form shall be a prerequisite to the issuance of the license. The information submitted on such form shall be considered exempt from Freedom of Information Act disclosure by the Village upon assertion as to its proprietary nature by the Refuse Collector. 
D.  Regulations. The applicant shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-19. - Wearing apparel stores. 
A.  Definition. "Wearing Apparel Stores" shall mean any place in which any wearing apparel, article of clothing, shoes, hats or articles of a like matter, are sold at retail directly to the consumer. 
B.  License Required. No person shall conduct or operate a wearing apparel store without obtaining a license therefor. 
C.  New Articles. It shall be unlawful for any person licensed under this Article to conduct or operate a wearing apparel store to sell any article which has been worn or used prior to the sale to the consumer, or to label, mark or hold out to the public that any article for sale is new and had not been previously worn or used, unless said article is in fact new and had not been previously worn or used. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-20. - Self-storage facilities. 
A.  Definition. "Self-Storage Facility" shall mean any building or other place within the Village which is improved with a structure containing separate modules for the storage of property. 
B.  Minimum Requirements. The following set for the minimum requirements applicable to any lot improved with a self-storage facility and to the building which is to be used as self-storage facility: 
1.  Each self-storage facility building shall be fireproof and waterproof. 
2.  Each separate module located within a self-storage facility shall have a separate ingress and egress which can be secured by the user thereof by a lock for which such user shall have his own key. 
3.  The zoning lot on which said self-storage facility is located shall be entirely enclosed with a minimum seven-foot high fence, shall be adequately lighted, and shall have on premises 24 hour continual security guard. 
4.  That the only exterior storage which shall be allowed on such premises shall consist of the parking of recreational vehicles, campers and boats, all of which must be parked on a paved area. 
5.  That the Fire, Police, Code Enforcement Departments of the Village shall have the right to inspect each module located within the self-storage facility at such times as such inspection is determined necessary by the Village Manager for the protection of the health, welfare and safety of the residents of the Village and the users of such facility. The licensee of such facility shall have available, at all times, the means of obtaining ingress to each separate module located within such facility. 
C.  License Required. No person, firm or corporation shall keep, conduct or operate a self-storage facility in the Village unless such premise meets the minimum requirements set forth above and the operator thereof has a current self-storage facility license. 
D.  Regulations. The applicant shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Fire Department and Department of Code Enforcement including the right of reasonable inspection. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-21. - Exterior drop boxes. 
A.  Definition. "Exterior Drop Box" shall mean any receptacle designed and placed for the purpose of receiving envelopes and packages for delivery by any person or corporation other than the U.S. Postal Service on the public right-of-way or upon private property not within or attached to any occupied structure. 
B.  License Required. No person shall place or maintain any exterior drop box without obtaining a permit therefor and said permit shall not be assigned. 
C.  Regulations. 
1.  Any exterior drop box placed upon the public right-of-way shall comply with the following requirements: 
a.  There shall be a one-time license agreement fee of $3,000.00 per corporation/owner that desires to install drop boxes upon the public right-of-way and said license shall not be assignable. 
b.  A licensing agreement between the Village and the owner shall be executed prior to any installations. 
c.  The licensing agreement will not be assignable except to a successor, owner or corporation by merger or buy-out. 
d.  The licensee shall indemnify and hold harmless the Village of Hoffman Estates against loss or damages to third persons property resulting directly from the installation and use of the drop box and not resulting from the negligent or wrongful acts of the Village of Hoffman Estates, its agents, or employees. 
e.  All locations in the right-of-way shall be subject to review and approval by the Department of Engineering prior to placement. 
2.  All exterior drop boxes shall comply with the following regulations: 
a.  Exterior drop boxes shall be installed only in Business, Manufacturing, Office and the Commercial portions of the Residential Planned Development Zoning Districts. 
b.  Exterior drop boxes shall not be placed on major streets as defined by Section 10-2-1 of the Hoffman Estates Municipal Code. 
c.  Exterior drop boxes must be placed at least two feet off the curb on minor streets as defined by Section 10-2-1 of the Hoffman Estates Municipal Code. 
d.  Exterior drop boxes placed on lawn areas must have a cement base. 
e.  The licensee shall deposit a $1,000.00 security deposit to insure that if the drop boxes are removed or abandoned by licensee, the licensee shall restore the property to good condition. 
f.  The area within 20 feet of all exterior drop boxes shall be kept free of debris. 
g.  All drop boxes shall be kept in good repair. 
h.  All drop boxes shall be grouped and installed in a straight line. 
i.  The total number of boxes allowed at any one location will be judged by the following criteria: 
(1)  Compatibility with zoning district. 
(2)  Nature of location (i.e., parking lot, intersection of minor and collector streets, private drives, etc.). 
(3)  Distance from driveways, corners and visibility triangles. 
(4)  Distance from any fire hydrant, other emergency facility, intersecting driveways, alleys, streets, marked cross walks, traffic signs or lights, and pedestrian passageways. 
(5)  Aesthetic impact on general location. 
j.  Exterior drop boxes shall not contain any advertising or promotional identification other than that which relates to the owner of the box. 
k.  Licenses shall be issued by the Village Clerk only upon written approval from the Department of Engineering. 
3.  The applicant shall comply with all regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement, the Department of Engineering and the Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-22. - Tanning facilities. 
A.  Definitions. 
1.  Tanning facility or tanning facilities means a room or a booth which houses ultraviolet lamps or products containing such lamps intended for the irradiation of any part of the living human body for cosmetic or nonmedical related purposes. 
2.  Tanning equipment means sunlamp products and ultraviolet lamps intended to include skin tanning through the irradiation of any part of the living human body. 
3.  Ultraviolet radiation for purposes of this Chapter will be referred to as follows: 
a.  UVA (ultraviolet A) radiation means radiation in the wavelength between 320 to 400 nanometers (one billionth). 
b.  UVB (ultraviolet B) radiation means radiation in the wavelength between 260 to 320 nanometers (one billionth). 
c.  UVC (ultraviolet C) radiation means radiation in the wavelength between 180 and 260 nanometers (one billionth). 
B.  License. No person shall operate or maintain a tanning facility without obtaining a license. 
C.  Regulations. 
1.  All tanning facilities shall comply with the following requirements: 
a.  No person under the age of 16 shall be permitted to use tanning equipment without prior approval of parent or guardian for each visit. 
b.  All tanning equipment shall be in compliance with standards set by the Department of Code Enforcement. 
c.  No tanning equipment shall be operated unless a trained operator is present at the facility. 
d.  The tanning facility shall post signs and warning as required by the Department of Code Enforcement. 
2.  The applicant shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement and the Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-23. - Newsracks. 
A.  Definitions. 
1.  Distributor shall mean the person responsible for placing and maintaining a newsrack in a public right-of-way. 
2.  Newsrack means any self-service or coin-operated box, container, storage unit or other dispenser installed, used or maintained for the display and sale of newspapers or other news periodicals. 
3.  Parkway means that area between the sidewalks and the curb of any street, and where there is no sidewalk, that area between the edge of the roadway and property line adjacent thereto. Parkway shall also include any area within a roadway which is not open to vehicular travel. 
4.  Roadway means that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. 
5.  Sidewalk means any surface provided for the exclusive use of pedestrians. 
6.  Street means all that area dedicated to public use for public street purposes and shall include, but not be limited to, roadways, parkways, alleys and sidewalks. 
B.  License Required. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to erect, place, maintain or operate, on any public street or sidewalk, or in any other public way or place, in the Village of Hoffman Estates any newsrack without obtaining a license from the Village of Hoffman Estates specifying the exact location of such newsrack(s). One license may be issued to include any number of newsracks and shall be signed by the applicant. 
C.  Regulations. 
1.  As an express condition of the acceptance of such license, the licensee thereby agrees to indemnify and save harmless the Village officers, directors and employees against any loss or liability of damage, including expenses and costs for bodily or personal injury, and for property damage sustained by any person as the result of the installation, use or maintenance of a newsrack within the Village of Hoffman Estates. 
2.  Licenses shall be used for the installation of a newsrack or newsracks without prior inspection of the location but such newsrack or newsracks and the installation, use or maintenance thereof shall be conditioned upon observance of the provisions of this Code. 
3.  Any newsrack which in whole or in part rests upon, in or over any public sidewalk or parkway, shall comply with the following materials: 
a.  No newsrack shall exceed four feet in height, 24 inches in width, or 20 inches in thickness. 
b.  No newsrack shall be used for advertising signs or publicity purposes other than that dealing with the display, sale or purchase of the newspaper or news periodical sold therein. 
c.  Each newsrack shall be equipped with a coin-return mechanism to permit a person using the machine to secure an immediate refund in the event he is unable to receive the publication paid for. The coin-return mechanisms shall be maintained in good working order. 
d.  Each newsrack shall have affixed to it in readily visible place so as to be seen by anyone using the newsrack a notice setting forth the name and address of the distributor and the telephone number of a working telephone service to call to report a malfunction of the coin-return mechanism, or to give the notices provided for in Subsection D-1. 
e.  Each newsrack shall be maintained in a neat and clean condition and in good repair at all times. Specifically, but without limiting the generality of the foregoing, each newsrack shall be serviced and maintained so that: 
(1)  it is reasonably free of dirt and grease. 
(2)  it is reasonably free of chipped, faded, peeling and cracked paint in the visible painted area thereof. 
(3)  it is reasonably free of rust and corrosion in the visible unpainted metal areas thereon. 
(4)  the clear plastic or glass parts thereof, if any, through which the publications therein are viewed are unbroken and reasonably free of cracks, dents, blemishes and discoloration. 
(5)  the paper or cardboard parts or inserts thereof are reasonably free of tears, peeling or fading. 
(6)  the structural parts thereof are not broken or unduly misshapen. 
f.  In the event a newsrack remains empty for a period of 30 continuous days, the same shall be deemed abandoned and in violation of these regulations. 
4.  Any newsrack which rests in whole or in part upon, or on any portion of a public right-of-way or which projects onto, into or over any part of a public right-of-way shall be located in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
a.  No newsrack shall be used or maintained which projects onto, into or over any part of the roadway of any public street, or which rests, wholly or in part upon, along or over any portion of the roadway of any public street. 
b.  No newsrack shall be permitted to rest upon, in or over any public sidewalk or parkway, when such installation, use or maintenance endangers the safety of persons or property, or when such site or location is used for public utility purposes, public transportation purposes or other governmental use, or when such newsrack unreasonably interferes with or impedes the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic including any legally marked or stopped vehicle, the ingress into or egress from any residence or place of business, or the use of poles, posts, traffic signs or signals, hydrants, mailboxes or other objects permitted at or near said location. 
c.  No newsrack shall be chained, bolted or otherwise attached to any fixture located in the public right-of-way, except to other newsracks. 
d.  Newsracks shall be placed next to each other, provided that no group of newsracks shall extend for a distance of more than eight feet along a curb, and a space of not less than three feet shall separate each group of newsracks. 
e.  No newsracks shall be placed, installed or used or maintained: 
(1)  within three feet of any marked crosswalk. 
(2)  within 12 feet of the curb return of any unmarked crosswalk. 
(3)  within five feet of any fire hydrant, fire call box or other emergency facility. 
(4)  within five feet of any driveway. 
(5)  within three feet ahead or 15 feet to the rear of any sign marking a designated bus stop. 
(6)  within three feet of the outer end of any bus bench. 
(7)  at any location whereby the clear space for the passageway of pedestrians is reduced to less than six feet. 
(8)  within three feet of or on any public area improved with flowers, shrubs, trees or other landscaping. 
(9)  within 300 feet of any other newsrack on the same side of the street in the same block containing the same issue or edition of the same publication. 
D.  Violations of Code and Appeal. 
1.  Upon determination by the Village Manager that a newsrack has been installed, used or maintained in violation of the provisions of this Code, an order to correct the offending condition will be issued to the distributor of the newsrack. Such order shall be telephoned to the distributor and confirmed by mailing a copy of the order by certified mail return receipt requested. The order shall specifically describe the offending condition and suggest actions necessary to correct the condition. Failure to properly correct the offending condition within three days (excluding Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays) after the mailing date of the order shall result in the offending newsrack being subject to an order to be summarily removed and processed as unclaimed property. 
2.  Any person or entity aggrieved by an order or a finding, determination, notice or action taken under the provisions of this Code may appeal and shall be appraised of his right to appeal to the Village President under Section 8-1-14 of this Code which shall include a right to a hearing. The licensee shall be given at least five days notice of the time and place of the hearing. The Village President shall give the licensee, and any other interested party, a reasonable opportunity to be heard, in order to show cause why the determination of the Village Manager should not be upheld. In all such cases, the burden of proof shall be upon the licensee to show that there was no substantial evidence to support the action taken by the Village Manager. At the conclusion of the hearing, the Village President shall make a final and conclusive determination. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-24. - Landscape material processing. 
A.  Definitions. 
1.  Landscape Material shall mean grass clippings, leaves, brush, branches and other such materials accumulated as a result of the care of lawns, shrubbery, vines and trees, but shall specifically exclude decomposed or composted materials. 
2.  Landscape Material Processing shall mean any business which accepts landscape waste generated off-site for the purpose of transferring the same to a permanent disposal facility or other off-site entity which may lawfully accept the same. 
B.  License Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of operating a landscape material processing business within the Village without having obtained a license therefor from the Village. 
C.  Regulations. It shall be the duty of the licensee of each landscape material processing business to: 
1.  Limit the operations on the site to the transfer of landscape waste, and to refuse and prevent the deposit upon, or transfer at, the site of any decomposed or composted materials; 
2.  Cause the site to be secured from entry at all times when operations are not permitted on the site; 
3.  Cause the inspection of the neighboring properties and surrounding public rights-of-way, and the removal therefrom of landscape wastes which fall, shift, blow, drop or escape from the site or the trucks operated in connection therewith, on a daily basis; 
4.  Cause all trucks operated in connection with the transfer of landscape waste off of the site to be securely covered with a tarpaulin or other cover so as to prevent the falling, shifting, blowing, dropping or escaping of any landscape wastes from such trucks, and to be operated in all respects in conformity with all applicable local, state and/or federal statutes, ordinances, rules and/or regulations, and to refuse to accept transfer of landscape waste onto the site from trucks which are not so covered; 
5.  Obtain all necessary permits, licenses and other approvals required by any applicable local, state and/or federal statutes, ordinances, rules and/or regulations, renew the same as necessary, and fully comply with all terms and conditions in connection therewith; 
6.  Permit the Village to inspect the site at any time during which operations are taking place, without prior notice, and at any times, upon reasonable notice; 
7.  Conduct the operations on the site so as to avoid any nuisance in fact, danger to life or detriment to health; 
8.  Comply with all applicable regulations of the Department of Code Enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-25. - Outdoor pay telephones. 
A.  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
1.  Outdoor pay telephone is any publicly accessible self-service, coin or credit card operated telephone. 
2.  Private outdoor pay telephone is any outdoor pay telephone located outside of a building which is not a public outdoor pay telephone. 
3.  Public outdoor pay telephone is any outdoor pay telephone or any portion of which, or its enclosure, is situated on, projects over, or hangs over a portion of the public right-of-way; or is situated such that it can be used by a person standing on the public right-of-way. 
4.  Public right-of-way is the full width of any dedicated street, alley or highway, including any parkway and public sidewalk. 
B.  Outdoor Pay Telephones; License Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to own or maintain an outdoor pay telephone without having obtained a license issued for that specific location. A license application shall list all locations by street address and shall list the telephone number for each outdoor pay telephone. No outdoor pay telephone shall be located on any private property without permission of the property owner. The address listed in the application shall be used by the Village for sending any required notices. 
C.  Public Outdoor Pay Telephones. It shall be unlawful for any person to install, construct or maintain a public outdoor pay telephone. 
D.  Private Outdoor Pay Telephones; Permitted Locations. It shall be unlawful for any person to install, own or maintain a private outdoor pay telephone under any of the following conditions: 
1.  On any vacant property. 
2.  On any property where there is an abandoned building. 
3.  On any property used for residential purposes. 
4.  At a location within 100 feet of and where the users of the telephone can be heard from a residential dwelling unit. 
E.  Restrictions on Service Provided. In order to combat conduct detrimental to the tranquility of the neighborhood, the Village may require that an outdoor pay telephone provide only one-way service such that incoming calls cannot be received. Such decision shall be made by the Village Manager based upon reported or documented incidents of conduct detrimental to the tranquility of the neighborhood. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-8-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE 9. - PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SWIMMING POOLS AND SPAS 

Sec. 8-9-1. - General application. 
A.  Compliance-General. No person shall construct, install or maintain any public or private swimming pool or spa in the Village without complying with all provisions of the Article. 
B.  Compliance-Substantial. Any public or private swimming pools or spas which were constructed or installed prior to and existed lawfully on April 1, 1998 shall be deemed to be in substantial compliance. 
C.  Definitions. As used in this Article, unless the context otherwise requires, the terms specified have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections. 
1.  Public Swimming Pool shall mean any artificial basin of water which is modified, improved, constructed or installed for the purpose of public swimming, and includes: pools for community use, pools at apartments, condominiums, townhomes, clubs, churches, camps, schools, institutions, parks, recreational areas, forest preserves, motels, hotels and other commercial establishments. This definition does not include swimming pools at private residences intended only for the use of the owner and guests. 
2.  Private Residential Swimming Pool shall mean any artificial basin of water over 24 inches in depth or having a capacity of 1,000 gallons or more which is constructed on or in-ground and which is used or intended to be used as a swimming pool in connection with a one- and two-family dwelling and is available to the family of the household and is private and not used for the purpose of profit. 
3.  Spa shall mean a hydromassage pool, or tub for therapeutic or recreational use, not located in health care facilities, and shall include, but is not limited to terms such as hydrotherapy pool, whirlpool, hot spa and hot tub. A spa is designed for the immersion of users but not for swimming and/or diving purposes and usually consists of a filter, heater and motor-driven blower. It may be installed indoors or outdoors, on the ground or supporting structure or in the ground or supporting structure. 
4.  In-Ground Swimming Pool shall mean any swimming pool that is constructed in the ground (below-grade) or in a building, in such a manner that the swimming pool cannot be readily disassembled for storage. 
5.  On-Ground Swimming Pools or Spas shall mean any swimming pool or spa whose sides rest fully or partially above the surrounding earth. 
6.  Temporary or Portable Swimming Pools shall mean any swimming pool that is constructed so that it may be readily disassembled for storage and reassembled to its original integrity or that it may be easily carried or moved by hand. 
7.  Barrier shall mean a fence, wall, building wall or combination thereof, which completely surrounds the swimming pool and obstructs access to the swimming pool. 
8.  Application shall mean any person making application for a permit or license. 
9.  Person shall mean any individual, group of individuals, association, trust, partnership or corporation. 
10.  Director of Code Enforcement shall mean the Director of Code Enforcement for the Village of Hoffman Estates. This term shall also include the designated representatives of the Director. 
11.  Village shall mean the Village of Hoffman Estates. 
12.  Revocation shall mean to declare invalid, for any definite period of time, a permit or license issued to the applicant or licensee issued by the Village. 
13.  State shall mean the State of Illinois, Department of Public Health. 
D.  Application for a Permit to Construct a Swimming Pool or Spa. No public or private swimming pool or spa, or appurtenances thereto, as defined by this Code shall be constructed, installed, enlarged or altered until a permit has been obtained from the Code Enforcement Division. 
1.  Application for a permit shall be in writing in the form supplied by the Director of Code Enforcement. Such application shall contain such information and drawings as shall be required by the Director of Code Enforcement for a proper understanding of the proposed work. 
Each application for permit to construct or alter a public pool or spa shall be accompanied by an approval permit for the construction issued by the State Department of Public Health. 
2.  No permit is required for erection of a portable or temporary swimming pool, if the capacity of such swimming pool is less than 1,000 gallons or depth does not exceed 24 inches. 
3.  Fees for permits required under this Chapter shall be established by the Village Board. 
E.  Swimming Pool and Spa Construction Plans and Standards. Plans shall accurately show dimensions and construction of swimming pool or spa and appurtenances and properly established distances to lot lines, buildings, walks and fences, details of water supply system, drainage and water disposal system; and all appurtenances pertaining to the swimming pool or spa. Detailed structures, vertical elevations and sections through the swimming pool showing depth shall be included. Applications and plans shall be reviewed to determine compliance with the following requirements: 
1.  Drainage. Drain outlet fittings from a swimming pool or spa shall not be connected to a sanitary sewer line. Drainage shall be by gravity, or by pumping or siphoning out into the top of a basin or sump located ahead of the storm drain sewer so as not to create a nuisance to adjacent properties or to the curb or gutter located along an adjacent street. 
2.  Grading. Issuance of a swimming pool or spa permit shall not include authorization to alter any lot grades or drainage swales unless a revised grading plan is approved by the Engineering Division in conjunction with the swimming pool permit. 
3.  Recirculation and Filtration System. Swimming pools with a capacity of 1,000 gallons or more and all spas shall be equipped with a water recirculation and filtration system. The equipment shall be capable of effecting one turnover of the swimming pool volume in eight hours or less. The equipment shall be capable of effecting one turnover of the spa volume in two hours or less. 
4.  Inlet Supply Fittings. In-ground swimming pools and spas shall be provided with at least two filtered water inlet supply fittings. 
5.  Outlet Fittings. The outlet fittings for in-ground swimming pools and spas which connect to the recirculation system shall be permanently installed at the lowest point in the swimming pool or spa. These fittings shall be ample in size, with a free grating area sufficient to minimize chances of clogging or occurrences of suction dangerous to the safety of bathers. The maximum width of the grate openings shall be 1/2-inch and be such that the bathers' body parts may not be caught or injured. All swimming pools and spas shall be equipped with a minimum of one skimmer. 
6.  Setback Lines. Swimming pools and spas shall be erected in locations specified in Chapter 9 (Zoning Code) of this Code. 
7.  Lighting. There shall be no lights placed on or about the swimming pool or spa that shine directly upon the property of other persons. 
8.  Steps or Ladders. All swimming pools shall have at least one means of egress. 
9.  Walk Areas. A walk area not less than four feet wide shall be provided to extend entirely around an in-ground swimming pool. The walk area shall consist of impervious materials of non-slip construction, shall be easily cleaned and have a definite pitch away from the swimming pool edge. 
10.  Barrier Requirements. The provisions of this section shall control the designs of barriers for residential swimming pools and spas. These design controls are intended to provide protection against potential drownings and near drownings by restricting access to swimming pools and spas. 
a)  Temporary or Portable Pools. Temporary or portable swimming pools over 24 inches in depth must be erected, filled and used within a fenced-in yard. 
b)  On-Ground Swimming Pools. The following barrier options shall be utilized: 
(1)  When a swimming pool is less than four-foot high (48 inches), a four-foot high (48-inch) fence with openings no greater than four inches, or a wall, shall completely surround the yard or swimming pool. The access to the swimming pool must still be protected. 
(2)  When a swimming pool that is four-foot high (48 inches) which has access by means of a ladder that is hinged and folds up latching in the up positions, or is easily and readily removable, a fence shall not be required. Such ladder shall remain latched in the up position or entirely removed from the swimming pool during the hours when the swimming pool is not in use. 
(3)  Should the ladder not fold up and latch or is not removable, a four-foot high (48-inch) fence with openings no greater than four inches with a self-closing, self-latching gate that completely surrounds the ladder must be installed. 
(4)  When the swimming pool is less than four-foot high (48 inches) a fence with openings no greater than four inches must be installed along the top of the swimming pool to maintain a height of four-foot (48 inches) from grade, or a four-foot high (48 inches) fence with openings no greater than four inches must completely surround the swimming pool. This fence must incorporate a ladder that is hinged and folds up latching in the up position. Such ladder shall remain latched in the up position during the hours when the swimming pool is not in use. 
(5)  Any deck which abuts any portion of a swimming pool shall have a minimum four-foot high (48 inches) guardrail/fence with openings no greater than four inches located along the portion of the deck that abuts the swimming pool. All gates within the fence shall be self-closing and self-latching. 
c)  In-Ground Swimming Pools. A four-foot high (48-inch) fence with openings no greater than four inches, or a wall which does not contain indentations or protrusions, shall completely surround the yard or in-ground swimming pool. 
d)  Alarms. A side of the house used for the safety barrier with doors with direct access to either an on-ground swimming pool or in-ground swimming pool shall have an audible alarm on the door that activates when the door and screen are opened. An approved power safety cover can be used in lieu of the door alarms. 
e)  Gates. All gates shall be equipped with self-closing, self-latching devices placed at a maximum of three inches below the top of the gate on the swimming pool side of the gate. On all gates that exceed five-foot high (60 inches) the self-closing, self-latching devices may be located on the outside of the gate with a minimum 54 inches from the bottom of the gate. 
No gate shall exceed six foot (72 inches) in height and openings in the gate shall not exceed four inches. 
All self-closing, self-latching devices must be locked during the hours when the swimming pool is not in use. 
f)  Spas. Spas must be equipped with an approved safety cover. 
11.  Electrical Requirements. All electrical wiring shall conform to the provisions of the National Electrical Code as adopted. No swimming pool or spa shall be located within ten feet of any overhead wiring or over or within five feet of any underground wiring. 
F.  Inspections. The Director of Code Enforcement shall have the right and authority to inspect any swimming pool or spa or to check the operation thereof during daylight hours. 
G.  Failure to Meet Requirement(s) . If the Director of Code Enforcement shall find, after inspection, that the operation of a Public Swimming Pool or Spa does not meet the safety requirements of this Chapter, the Director shall order the Public Swimming Pool or Spa be closed until the safety requirements are met. Where additional inspections are made because of inaccurate or incorrect information, failure to make necessary repairs, or faulty construction, a charge of $50.00 shall be made for each such inspection. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11; Ord. No. 4409-2014, § 1, 1-20-14) 
Sec. 8-9-2. - Public swimming pools and spas. 
A.  State Requirements by Reference. The design and construction of public swimming pools and spas shall comply with the regulations and requirements of the Illinois Swimming Pool and Bathing Beach Code as set forth in the rules and regulations adopted by the Department of Public Health for State of Illinois as of May 25, 1996 and as amended. 
B.  Annual Operation License. 
1.  An annual operating license shall be required for all public swimming pools and spas. The operating license shall be renewed annually or whenever a swimming pool or spa is to be reopened for use after being closed for a period longer than three months. 
2.  The Director of Code Enforcement shall make an inspection of the swimming pool or spa before an annual operating license is issued. Subsequent inspections of the swimming pool or spa shall be made as required by the Director of Code Enforcement. 
3.  The annual operating license fee for public swimming pools or spas shall be in accordance with the fee schedule established by this Code. 
C.  Regulations. The permit holder must comply with all applicable regulations of the Code Enforcement Division including those regarding operational requirements, safety equipment, enclosures, operation and maintenance, bather load, gas chlorinators, water quality and right of inspection. 
D.  Reopening of Public Swimming Pools and Spas Closed for One Year or Longer. Public swimming pools or spas closed for a period of one year or longer shall not be reopened without the prior approval of the State Department of Public Health and the Hoffman Estates Code Enforcement Division. Copies of such letters of approval shall accompany the application to reopen the swimming pool or spa. 
(Ord. No. 4238-2011, § 3(Exh. A), 5-2-11) 
Sec. 8-9-3. - Private residential swimming pools and spas. 
A.  Permit Regulations. No permit shall be issued for a private swimming pool or spa or any accessory building unless a permit for a dwelling is issued in connection therewith or a dwelling is already located on the same lot. 
B.  Water Supply. 
1.  The water supply to a swimming pool shall be protected by means of a proper air gap. If an air gap is not possible, the water supply shall have an appropriate cross connection control device. 
C.  Maintenance Responsibility. 
1.  The swimming pool owner shall be instructed in the care and maintenance of the swimming pool by the supplier or builder, including treatment with high-test calcium hypochlorite (dry chlorine), sodium hypochlorite (liquid chlorine) or equally effective germicide and algicide approved by the Code Enforcement Division, and the importance of proper pH (alkalinity and acidity) control. 
2.  No person shall allow their swimming pool or spa to collect and hold stagnant water that allows for insect breeding or public nuisance. When such a swimming pool or spa is found to exist, the Code Enforcement Division shall require the homeowner to completely drain such swimming pool or spa and either refill and maintain such swimming pool or spa in a clean and sanitary manner or disassemble and remove said swimming pool or spa.
